title: Volcán de Fuego
meta_title: Volcán de Fuego — Eruptions, Height & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Volcán de Fuego is a 3,799 m active stratovolcano in Guatemala. Explore its full eruption history, the deadly 2018 disaster, current status, and hazard map.

quick_answer.what: Volcán de Fuego (Volcano of Fire) is an active stratovolcano rising 3,799 m (12,464 ft) above sea level in south-central Guatemala, approximately 16 km southwest of the former colonial capital, Antigua Guatemala.
quick_answer.status: Active — in near-continuous eruption since 2002. One of the most active volcanoes in Central America and the world.
quick_answer.famous_for: The catastrophic June 3, 2018 eruption that sent pyroclastic flows into surrounding villages, killing at least 431 people and becoming the deadliest volcanic event in Guatemala's modern history.
quick_answer.danger_level: Extremely high — dense rural and semi-urban populations on its lower flanks, with tens of thousands of people living within its lahar and pyroclastic flow hazard zones.

overview.content: Volcán de Fuego is an active stratovolcano rising to 3,799 m (12,464 ft) in south-central Guatemala, approximately 16 km (10 mi) southwest of the UNESCO World Heritage city of Antigua Guatemala. It is one of Central America's most active and dangerous volcanoes, with 79 recorded eruptions dating back to 1524 — the year of the Spanish conquest — and geological evidence of activity stretching to at least 1580 BCE. Fuego forms part of a volcanic massif shared with Acatenango to the north and the remnants of the older Meseta edifice between them, representing a southward migration of volcanism over the past 230,000 years. The volcano's activity is driven by the subduction of the Cocos Plate beneath the Caribbean Plate along the Middle America Trench, a tectonic engine that also powers the entire Central American Volcanic Arc. Unlike many of its andesitic neighbors, Fuego erupts predominantly basaltic magma, producing frequent Strombolian and Vulcanian explosions, lava flows, and — during its largest events — devastating pyroclastic flows and lahars. Since January 2002, Fuego has been in a state of near-continuous eruption, making it one of the most persistently active volcanoes on Earth alongside Stromboli and Kilauea. The catastrophic eruption of June 3, 2018, which killed at least 431 people, thrust Fuego onto the global stage as a stark reminder of the lethal threat posed by volcanoes in densely populated tropical regions. Among the world's most active volcanoes, Fuego ranks as one of the most frequently erupting stratovolcanoes in the Western Hemisphere.

geology_and_formation.content: Volcán de Fuego sits within the Central American Volcanic Arc, a chain of approximately 50 active volcanoes stretching 1,500 km from Guatemala to Panama, generated by the subduction of the oceanic Cocos Plate beneath the continental Caribbean Plate at a rate of roughly 7–8 cm per year. The Fuego–Acatenango massif represents a complex volcanic center with a history spanning at least 230,000 years. The oldest component, Meseta, is a deeply eroded ancestral edifice whose construction began around 230,000 years ago and continued into the late Pleistocene or early Holocene. The collapse of Meseta produced the massive Escuintla debris-avalanche deposit, which extends approximately 50 km (31 mi) onto the Pacific coastal plain — one of the largest volcanic landslide deposits in Central America. The modern Fuego cone grew southward of Meseta, continuing a pattern of vent migration from the dominantly andesitic Acatenango toward increasingly mafic compositions. Today, Fuego erupts primarily basaltic to picritic-basaltic lavas, a composition that is unusually mafic for a large continental-arc stratovolcano. This basaltic character gives Fuego's eruptions their characteristic incandescent fountain displays and relatively fluid lava flows, but the volcano is fully capable of generating viscous pyroclastic flows during its larger events. The current summit cone sits within a 5-km-wide breach open to the south, carved by repeated sector collapses. Fuego's edifice rises approximately 2,500 m above the adjacent Pacific lowlands, making it one of the tallest and most imposing volcanic structures in Guatemala.

eruption_history_overview.content: Fuego's recorded eruption history is one of the longest in the Americas, beginning with the arrival of Spanish conquistadors in 1524. The Smithsonian Global Volcanism Program catalogs 79 eruptions, of which 61 are confirmed. Geological evidence pushes the record back to approximately 1580 BCE. The volcano has produced eruptions across a range of intensities, with VEI values from 1 to 4, though VEI 2 events dominate the record (47 occurrences). Seven eruptions reached VEI 4, including devastating paroxysms in 1581, 1717, 1737, 1857, 1880, 1932, and 1974. Activity has been remarkably persistent: every century since the 16th has seen at least 10 eruptions, and the 20th century alone recorded 20. The current eruptive episode, which began in January 2002, represents the longest sustained period of activity in the historical record, producing hundreds of individual explosive pulses, multiple lava flows, and several significant pyroclastic flow events — most catastrophically on June 3, 2018.

subsections.title: The 2018 Eruption — Guatemala's Deadliest Modern Volcanic Disaster
subsections.content: On June 3, 2018, Volcán de Fuego produced a sudden, violent paroxysmal eruption that would become the deadliest volcanic event in Guatemala in over a century, and one of the deadliest eruptions anywhere in the world since Nevado del Ruiz in 1985. The eruption began with an intensification of the ongoing eruptive activity around midday, generating an eruption column that rose to approximately 15 km (49,000 ft) above sea level. The critical phase came when pyroclastic flows — superheated avalanches of gas, ash, and rock fragments traveling at speeds of 100–200 km/h (60–125 mph) and temperatures exceeding 700°C (1,300°F) — surged down the Barranca Las Lajas on Fuego's southeastern flank. These flows traveled over 12 km from the summit, engulfing the communities of San Miguel Los Lotes and El Rodeo in the municipality of Escuintla. The village of San Miguel Los Lotes was virtually obliterated, buried under several meters of hot volcanic debris. The official death toll stood at 431, with approximately 256 people still listed as missing. Nearly 13,000 people were evacuated, and over 1.7 million were affected across three departments. The tragedy was compounded by delayed evacuation warnings: INSIVUMEH and CONRED (the national disaster agency) were criticized for not issuing evacuation orders until pyroclastic flows had already reached populated areas. The 2018 disaster highlighted the extreme vulnerability of communities living on the flanks of active volcanoes in developing nations, where population growth pushes settlements ever closer to hazard zones.

subsections.title: The 1974 Eruption — Fuego's Most Powerful 20th-Century Paroxysm
subsections.content: Between October 10 and 23, 1974, Fuego produced a VEI 4 eruption that was the most powerful at the volcano in over 90 years. The eruption generated an ash column reaching approximately 15 km above sea level, deposited tephra over an area exceeding 100 km downwind, and produced significant pyroclastic flows that descended the volcano's southern drainages. Lava flows extended several kilometers down the flanks. The 1974 event was extensively studied and became a benchmark for understanding sub-Plinian basaltic eruptions at arc stratovolcanoes, challenging the assumption that only silicic magmas could produce highly explosive behavior. Communities in the surrounding area were heavily affected by ashfall, though casualties were limited due to the relatively sparse population on the volcano's immediate flanks at the time.

subsections.title: The 1932 Eruption — Major Explosive Event
subsections.content: The VEI 4 eruption of January 21, 1932, was one of Fuego's most violent 20th-century events. The eruption produced substantial pyroclastic flows and heavy ashfall that affected agricultural communities across the central highlands. The 1932 event was among a cluster of major eruptions — including the 1717, 1737, and 1880 events — that demonstrate Fuego's capacity for sudden, explosive paroxysms interspersed with decades of lower-level activity. Reports from the era describe incandescent material visible from Antigua and ashfall reaching Guatemala City, approximately 45 km to the east.

subsections.title: The 1717 Eruption — Colonial-Era Catastrophe
subsections.content: The eruption of August 27, 1717, rated VEI 4, was one of the most destructive events in Fuego's colonial-era record. Historical accounts describe violent explosions, heavy ashfall across the Antigua valley, pyroclastic flows, and lahars that devastated communities on the volcano's lower slopes. The eruption contributed to the decision to relocate Guatemala's capital, which eventually moved from Antigua to present-day Guatemala City in 1776 following the devastating Santa Marta earthquakes — though Fuego's repeated eruptions had already made the region's hazards abundantly clear. A second VEI 4 eruption followed in 1737, reinforcing Fuego's reputation as the most dangerous of the three volcanoes visible from Antigua.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Volcán de Fuego has been in near-continuous eruption since January 4, 2002, making its current eruptive episode over 23 years in duration. Activity typically consists of Strombolian explosions at the summit producing ash plumes rising 1–2 km above the crater, incandescent ballistic ejections visible at night, and periodic lava flows descending the Barranca Ceniza, Barranca Trinidad, and Barranca Las Lajas drainages. Paroxysmal episodes — sudden, intense escalations lasting hours to days — occur several times per year, generating larger eruption columns, pyroclastic flows, and significant ashfall. INSIVUMEH, Guatemala's national monitoring agency, operates a seismic network around Fuego, augmented by infrasound sensors, web cameras, and satellite-based thermal monitoring through the MIROVA and MODVOLC systems. The Washington Volcanic Ash Advisory Center (VAAC) issues regular alerts for aviation. Despite improvements since the 2018 disaster, monitoring capacity remains limited relative to the scale of the hazard. Community early-warning systems have been expanded, and evacuation routes have been improved, but significant challenges remain in communicating risk to populations who depend on fertile volcanic soils for their livelihoods.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Fuego presents a comprehensive range of volcanic hazards. Pyroclastic flows are the most lethal threat, as demonstrated in 2018, capable of traveling more than 12 km from the summit at devastating speeds through the deeply incised barrancas (ravines) that channel them into populated lowlands. Lahars — volcanic mudflows triggered by rainfall mixing with loose deposits — are a persistent secondary hazard, especially during Guatemala's rainy season (May–October), and can affect communities along river drainages extending 30–50 km from the summit onto the Pacific coastal plain. Ashfall regularly affects the Antigua valley, the city of Escuintla (population ~170,000), and occasionally reaches Guatemala City (population ~3 million), disrupting aviation, agriculture, and daily life. Ballistic projectiles endanger areas within 3–5 km of the summit, and lava flows — though generally slow-moving — have descended several kilometers during paroxysmal episodes. CONRED has established hazard zones and evacuation protocols, but enforcement is complicated by poverty, land tenure issues, and the agricultural dependence of communities living on Fuego's fertile flanks. The 2018 disaster killed at least 431 people in communities that had received inadequate warning, highlighting the gap between scientific monitoring and effective risk communication. Fuego is considered one of the most dangerous volcanoes in the Americas, comparable in threat level to Merapi in Indonesia and Popocatépetl in Mexico.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Volcán de Fuego is an imposing, symmetrical stratovolcano that dominates the skyline of south-central Guatemala. Its summit, at 3,799 m (12,464 ft), rises approximately 2,500 m above the Pacific coastal plain to the south and 2,200 m above the Antigua valley to the northeast. The summit crater is approximately 250 m in diameter and open to the south, the direction toward which most eruptive products are channeled. The volcano's flanks are deeply incised by a system of barrancas — steep-walled ravines carved by lahars and pyroclastic flows — that radiate outward from the summit, including the Barranca Las Lajas, Barranca El Jute, Barranca Ceniza, Barranca Trinidad, and Barranca Honda. These barrancas serve as natural conduits that focus hazardous flows toward lowland communities. Fuego is closely linked to Acatenango (3,976 m / 13,045 ft), its dormant twin peak located just 5 km to the north, and the remnants of the ancestral Meseta edifice lie between them. The three peaks — Fuego, Acatenango, and Meseta — form a dramatic NNE–SSW aligned massif. The lower slopes of the volcano are cloaked in subtropical forest, transitioning to sparse alpine vegetation above 3,000 m and barren volcanic terrain near the summit. Coffee plantations, sugar cane fields, and subsistence farms extend up the lower flanks, placing agricultural communities directly within hazard zones.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Fuego's eruptions have generally been of insufficient magnitude to produce measurable global climate effects. Its largest historical events (VEI 4) injected ash and sulfur dioxide into the upper troposphere but did not reach the stratosphere in quantities sufficient to affect hemispheric temperatures. However, the volcano's persistent degassing contributes significantly to regional atmospheric sulfur dioxide concentrations, and its frequent ash emissions pose chronic hazards to aviation across Central America and southern Mexico. The 2018 eruption generated a plume that disrupted flights at La Aurora International Airport in Guatemala City. In a broader context, Fuego's eruptions are modest compared to climate-altering events like Tambora (1815, VEI 7) or Pinatubo (1991, VEI 6), but its relentless activity makes it a significant contributor to the regional volcanic aerosol budget.

cultural_significance.content: Volcán de Fuego — whose name translates to 'Volcano of Fire' in Spanish — has been central to Guatemalan culture and identity since before the Spanish conquest. Pre-Columbian Maya peoples revered the volcano as a sacred mountain, and the Kaqchikel Maya name for the volcano, Chi Q'aq', also means 'where the fire is.' The volcano, together with Acatenango and Agua, forms the iconic trio of peaks visible from Antigua Guatemala, a UNESCO World Heritage Site founded in 1543. Fuego's frequent nighttime eruptions — glowing fountains of lava visible from the cobblestone streets of Antigua — have drawn travelers and painters for centuries. The volcano was a prominent feature in accounts by early European travelers to Central America. In modern Guatemala, Fuego's 2018 eruption has become a defining national tragedy. The destruction of San Miguel Los Lotes is commemorated annually, and the disaster triggered significant debate about disaster preparedness, indigenous community rights, and government accountability. The volcano remains a popular hiking destination, typically climbed via the neighboring Acatenango summit, from which Fuego's eruptions can be observed at close range — one of the most dramatic volcanic viewing experiences on Earth.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Volcán de Fuego itself is not open for summit hiking due to the extreme danger of its ongoing eruptions. However, the neighboring Acatenango volcano is one of Central America's most popular overnight hikes, offering front-row views of Fuego's eruptions from a relatively safe distance of approximately 5 km. Most guided tours depart from Antigua Guatemala and involve a strenuous 6–8 hour hike to a campsite at approximately 3,700 m on Acatenango's flanks, where hikers spend the night watching Fuego's incandescent explosions illuminate the darkness. The experience is widely considered one of the most spectacular volcanic tourism opportunities in the world. The hike is available year-round but conditions are best during the dry season (November–April). Altitude sickness, hypothermia at the campsite, and sudden weather changes are real risks. All visitors should use accredited guides and register with local authorities. The Antigua valley itself offers numerous viewpoints of Fuego, and the Cerro de la Cruz lookout provides a classic panorama of the volcano towering over the colonial city.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Fuego is part of a remarkably dense cluster of volcanic activity in south-central Guatemala. Its immediate neighbor, Acatenango (3,976 m), lies just 5 km to the north and last erupted in 1972. Volcán de Agua (3,760 m), a dormant stratovolcano to the east, completes the trio visible from Antigua. Further along the Central American Volcanic Arc, Pacaya (2,552 m), located 25 km to the southeast, is another frequently active basaltic volcano. To the west, the massive Santa María volcano (3,772 m) hosts the continuously erupting Santiaguito lava dome complex, and Atitlán and Tolimán overlook the iconic Lake Atitlán caldera. Guatemala has 22 Holocene volcanoes in total, making it one of the most volcanically active nations in the world relative to its size.

etymology.content: The name 'Fuego' is Spanish for 'fire,' reflecting the volcano's persistent incandescent eruptions observed since the earliest European contact in the 16th century. Spanish colonial records frequently refer to it as 'Volcán de Fuego' (Volcano of Fire). In the Kaqchikel Maya language, the volcano is known as Chi Q'aq', meaning 'where the fire is' or 'at the fire.' The volcano is also sometimes locally called 'Volcán de Fuego de Guatemala' to distinguish it from Volcán de Colima, also known as Volcán de Fuego, in Mexico.

faqs.question: Is Volcán de Fuego still erupting?
faqs.answer: Yes, Volcán de Fuego has been in near-continuous eruption since January 2002, making it one of the most persistently active volcanoes on Earth. Typical activity consists of Strombolian explosions at the summit producing ash plumes rising 1–2 km above the crater, incandescent lava fountains, and periodic lava flows. Several times per year, activity intensifies into paroxysmal episodes producing larger eruption columns, pyroclastic flows, and significant ashfall. INSIVUMEH, Guatemala's volcanological institute, monitors Fuego continuously and issues regular bulletins. The volcano shows no signs of returning to dormancy.

faqs.question: How many people died in the 2018 Fuego eruption?
faqs.answer: The official death toll from the June 3, 2018 eruption stands at 431 people, with approximately 256 additional people still listed as missing and presumed dead. The majority of victims were in the communities of San Miguel Los Lotes and El Rodeo in Escuintla department, which were engulfed by pyroclastic flows descending the Barranca Las Lajas. Nearly 13,000 people were evacuated, and over 1.7 million were affected. The disaster was Guatemala's deadliest volcanic event in modern history and one of the deadliest volcanic eruptions worldwide since Nevado del Ruiz killed approximately 23,000 people in Colombia in 1985.

faqs.question: How tall is Volcán de Fuego?
faqs.answer: Volcán de Fuego stands 3,799 m (12,464 ft) above sea level, making it one of the tallest active volcanoes in Central America. Its summit rises approximately 2,500 m above the Pacific coastal plain to the south. Fuego is slightly shorter than its dormant twin, Acatenango (3,976 m / 13,045 ft), located just 5 km to the north, and nearly identical in height to neighboring Volcán de Agua (3,760 m / 12,336 ft). For comparison, Guatemala's tallest volcano is Tajumulco at 4,220 m (13,845 ft).

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Fuego?
faqs.answer: Fuego is a stratovolcano (also called a composite volcano), built up by alternating layers of lava flows, ash deposits, and pyroclastic material over tens of thousands of years. It is part of the Fuego–Acatenango volcanic complex, which includes the older Meseta and Acatenango edifices. Unusually for a large stratovolcano on continental crust, Fuego erupts predominantly basaltic magma rather than the more typical andesite or dacite. This basaltic composition produces spectacular lava fountains and relatively fluid lava flows, though the volcano is fully capable of generating explosive eruptions up to VEI 4.

faqs.question: Can you hike Volcán de Fuego?
faqs.answer: Climbing the summit of Volcán de Fuego itself is extremely dangerous and not permitted due to its ongoing eruption. However, the neighboring Acatenango volcano offers one of the world's most spectacular volcanic hiking experiences. Guided overnight trips from Antigua Guatemala involve a 6–8 hour hike to a campsite at approximately 3,700 m on Acatenango's flanks, where hikers spend the night watching Fuego's eruptions from about 5 km away. The dry season (November–April) offers the best conditions. Accredited guides and proper cold-weather gear are essential, as temperatures at the campsite can drop below freezing.

faqs.question: Why was the 2018 eruption so deadly?
faqs.answer: Several factors combined to make the June 3, 2018 eruption devastating. First, pyroclastic flows — not lava or ashfall — were the primary killer, traveling at 100–200 km/h down deeply incised ravines (barrancas) that channeled them directly into populated communities. Second, the communities of San Miguel Los Lotes and El Rodeo had grown into high-risk zones on the volcano's lower flanks. Third, evacuation warnings were delayed: the eruption intensified rapidly, and authorities did not issue evacuation orders until flows had already reached populated areas. Fourth, limited monitoring infrastructure and communication systems hampered early detection of the paroxysm's severity.

faqs.question: How often does Fuego erupt?
faqs.answer: Fuego has been in near-continuous eruption since January 2002, producing daily Strombolian explosions and periodic more intense events. Over its full recorded history dating to 1524, Fuego has produced 79 eruptions — an average of roughly one eruption every 6–7 years, though activity has been clustered in active periods. The 16th century saw 17 eruptions, and the 20th century recorded 20. Several times per year, the volcano experiences paroxysmal episodes producing larger eruption columns and pyroclastic flows. Fuego ranks among the five most frequently erupting volcanoes in the Western Hemisphere.

faqs.question: What is the difference between Fuego and Acatenango?
faqs.answer: Fuego and Acatenango are twin volcanoes located just 5 km apart, forming a single volcanic massif, but they differ significantly. Fuego (3,799 m) is one of the most active volcanoes in the Americas, erupting basaltic magma in near-continuous Strombolian activity since 2002. Acatenango (3,976 m) is dormant, having last erupted in 1972, and produces more typical andesitic magma. Geologically, they represent a southward migration of volcanism: the older Acatenango gave way to the younger, more mafic Fuego. Today, Acatenango serves as a safe vantage point for observing Fuego's eruptions.
